146  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">chunked(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">strict=</span><span class="s0">False</span><span class="s1">):</span>
147      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Break *iterable* into lists of length *n*: 
148   
149          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(chunked([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6], 3)) 
150          [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] 
151   
152      By the default, the last yielded list will have fewer than *n* elements 
153      if the length of *iterable* is not divisible by *n*: 
154   
155          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(chunked([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], 3)) 
156          [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8]] 
157   
158      To use a fill-in value instead, see the :func:`grouper` recipe. 
159   
160      If the length of *iterable* is not divisible by *n* and *strict* is 
161      ``True``, then ``ValueError`` will be raised before the last 
162      list is yielded. 
163   
164      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
165      <span class="s1">iterator = iter(partial(take</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iter(iterable))</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">[])</span>
166      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">strict:</span>
167  
168          <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">ret():</span>
169              <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">chunk </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iterator:</span>
170                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">len(chunk) != n:</span>
171                      <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'iterable is not divisible by n.'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
172                  <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">chunk</span>
173  
174          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iter(ret())</span>
175      <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
176          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iterator</span>
177

179  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">first(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=_marker):</span>
180      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the first item of *iterable*, or *default* if *iterable* is 
181      empty. 
182   
183          &gt;&gt;&gt; first([0, 1, 2, 3]) 
184          0 
185          &gt;&gt;&gt; first([], 'some default') 
186          'some default' 
187   
188      If *default* is not provided and there are no items in the iterable, 
189      raise ``ValueError``. 
190   
191      :func:`first` is useful when you have a generator of expensive-to-retrieve 
192      values and want any arbitrary one. It is marginally shorter than 
193      ``next(iter(iterable), default)``. 
194   
195      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
196      <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
197          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">next(iter(iterable))</span>
198      <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration </span><span class="s0">as </span><span class="s1">e:</span>
199          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">default </span><span class="s0">is </span><span class="s1">_marker:</span>
200              <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span>
201                  <span class="s2">'first() was called on an empty iterable, and no '</span>
202                  <span class="s2">'default value was provided.'</span>
203              <span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">from </span><span class="s1">e</span>
204          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">default</span>
205

207  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">last(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=_marker):</span>
208      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the last item of *iterable*, or *default* if *iterable* is 
209      empty. 
210   
211          &gt;&gt;&gt; last([0, 1, 2, 3]) 
212          3 
213          &gt;&gt;&gt; last([], 'some default') 
214          'some default' 
215   
216      If *default* is not provided and there are no items in the iterable, 
217      raise ``ValueError``. 
218      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
219      <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
220          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">isinstance(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">Sequence):</span>
221              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iterable[-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]</span>
222          <span class="s5"># Work around https://bugs.python.org/issue38525</span>
223          <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">hasattr(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s2">'__reversed__'</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">and </span><span class="s1">(hexversion != </span><span class="s4">0x030800F0</span><span class="s1">):</span>
224              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">next(reversed(iterable))</span>
225          <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
226              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">deque(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">maxlen=</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)[-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]</span>
227      <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">(IndexError</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">TypeError</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">StopIteration):</span>
228          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">default </span><span class="s0">is </span><span class="s1">_marker:</span>
229              <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span>
230                  <span class="s2">'last() was called on an empty iterable, and no default was '</span>
231                  <span class="s2">'provided.'</span>
232              <span class="s1">)</span>
233          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">default</span>
234

236  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">nth_or_last(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=_marker):</span>
237      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the nth or the last item of *iterable*, 
238      or *default* if *iterable* is empty. 
239   
240          &gt;&gt;&gt; nth_or_last([0, 1, 2, 3], 2) 
241          2 
242          &gt;&gt;&gt; nth_or_last([0, 1], 2) 
243          1 
244          &gt;&gt;&gt; nth_or_last([], 0, 'some default') 
245          'some default' 
246   
247      If *default* is not provided and there are no items in the iterable, 
248      raise ``ValueError``. 
249      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
250      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">last(islice(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=default)</span>

252  
253  <span class="s0">class </span><span class="s1">peekable:</span>
254      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Wrap an iterator to allow lookahead and prepending elements. 
255   
256      Call :meth:`peek` on the result to get the value that will be returned 
257      by :func:`next`. This won't advance the iterator: 
258   
259          &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable(['a', 'b']) 
260          &gt;&gt;&gt; p.peek() 
261          'a' 
262          &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
263          'a' 
264   
265      Pass :meth:`peek` a default value to return that instead of raising 
266      ``StopIteration`` when the iterator is exhausted. 
267   
268          &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable([]) 
269          &gt;&gt;&gt; p.peek('hi') 
270          'hi' 
271   
272      peekables also offer a :meth:`prepend` method, which &quot;inserts&quot; items 
273      at the head of the iterable: 
274   
275          &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable([1, 2, 3]) 
276          &gt;&gt;&gt; p.prepend(10, 11, 12) 
277          &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
278          10 
279          &gt;&gt;&gt; p.peek() 
280          11 
281          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(p) 
282          [11, 12, 1, 2, 3] 
283   
284      peekables can be indexed. Index 0 is the item that will be returned by 
285      :func:`next`, index 1 is the item after that, and so on: 
286      The values up to the given index will be cached. 
287   
288          &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable(['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']) 
289          &gt;&gt;&gt; p[0] 
290          'a' 
291          &gt;&gt;&gt; p[1] 
292          'b' 
293          &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
294          'a' 
295   
296      Negative indexes are supported, but be aware that they will cache the 
297      remaining items in the source iterator, which may require significant 
298      storage. 
299   
300      To check whether a peekable is exhausted, check its truth value: 
301   
302          &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable(['a', 'b']) 
303          &gt;&gt;&gt; if p:  # peekable has items 
304          ...     list(p) 
305          ['a', 'b'] 
306          &gt;&gt;&gt; if not p:  # peekable is exhausted 
307          ...     list(p) 
308          [] 
309   
310      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
311  
312      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__init__(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable):</span>
313          <span class="s1">self._it = iter(iterable)</span>
314          <span class="s1">self._cache = deque()</span>
315  
316      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__iter__(self):</span>
317          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self</span>
318  
319      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__bool__(self):</span>
320          <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
321              <span class="s1">self.peek()</span>
322          <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
323              <span class="s0">return False</span>
324          <span class="s0">return True</span>
325  
326      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">peek(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=_marker):</span>
327          <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the item that will be next returned from ``next()``. 
328   
329          Return ``default`` if there are no items left. If ``default`` is not 
330          provided, raise ``StopIteration``. 
331   
332          &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
333          <span class="s0">if not </span><span class="s1">self._cache:</span>
334              <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
335                  <span class="s1">self._cache.append(next(self._it))</span>
336              <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
337                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">default </span><span class="s0">is </span><span class="s1">_marker:</span>
338                      <span class="s0">raise</span>
339                  <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">default</span>
340          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self._cache[</span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">]</span>
341  
342      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">prepend(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">*items):</span>
343          <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Stack up items to be the next ones returned from ``next()`` or 
344          ``self.peek()``. The items will be returned in 
345          first in, first out order:: 
346   
347              &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable([1, 2, 3]) 
348              &gt;&gt;&gt; p.prepend(10, 11, 12) 
349              &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
350              10 
351              &gt;&gt;&gt; list(p) 
352              [11, 12, 1, 2, 3] 
353   
354          It is possible, by prepending items, to &quot;resurrect&quot; a peekable that 
355          previously raised ``StopIteration``. 
356   
357              &gt;&gt;&gt; p = peekable([]) 
358              &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
359              Traceback (most recent call last): 
360                ... 
361              StopIteration 
362              &gt;&gt;&gt; p.prepend(1) 
363              &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
364              1 
365              &gt;&gt;&gt; next(p) 
366              Traceback (most recent call last): 
367                ... 
368              StopIteration 
369   
370          &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
371          <span class="s1">self._cache.extendleft(reversed(items))</span>
372  
373      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__next__(self):</span>
374          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">self._cache:</span>
375              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self._cache.popleft()</span>
376  
377          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">next(self._it)</span>
378  
379      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">_get_slice(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">index):</span>
380          <span class="s5"># Normalize the slice's arguments</span>
381          <span class="s1">step = </span><span class="s4">1 </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(index.step </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">index.step</span>
382          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">step &gt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
383              <span class="s1">start = </span><span class="s4">0 </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(index.start </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">index.start</span>
384              <span class="s1">stop = maxsize </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(index.stop </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">index.stop</span>
385          <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">step &lt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
386              <span class="s1">start = -</span><span class="s4">1 </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(index.start </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">index.start</span>
387              <span class="s1">stop = (-maxsize - </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(index.stop </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">index.stop</span>
388          <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
389              <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'slice step cannot be zero'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
390  
391          <span class="s5"># If either the start or stop index is negative, we'll need to cache</span>
392          <span class="s5"># the rest of the iterable in order to slice from the right side.</span>
393          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(start &lt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">(stop &lt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">):</span>
394              <span class="s1">self._cache.extend(self._it)</span>
395          <span class="s5"># Otherwise we'll need to find the rightmost index and cache to that</span>
396          <span class="s5"># point.</span>
397          <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
398              <span class="s1">n = min(max(start</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">stop) + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">maxsize)</span>
399              <span class="s1">cache_len = len(self._cache)</span>
400              <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n &gt;= cache_len:</span>
401                  <span class="s1">self._cache.extend(islice(self._it</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n - cache_len))</span>
402  
403          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">list(self._cache)[index]</span>
404  
405      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__getitem__(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">index):</span>
406          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">isinstance(index</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">slice):</span>
407              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self._get_slice(index)</span>
408  
409          <span class="s1">cache_len = len(self._cache)</span>
410          <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">index &lt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
411              <span class="s1">self._cache.extend(self._it)</span>
412          <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">index &gt;= cache_len:</span>
413              <span class="s1">self._cache.extend(islice(self._it</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">index + </span><span class="s4">1 </span><span class="s1">- cache_len))</span>
414  
415          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self._cache[index]</span>
416  
417  
418  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">collate(*iterables</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">**kwargs):</span>
419      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return a sorted merge of the items from each of several already-sorted 
420      *iterables*. 
421   
422          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collate('ACDZ', 'AZ', 'JKL')) 
423          ['A', 'A', 'C', 'D', 'J', 'K', 'L', 'Z', 'Z'] 
424   
425      Works lazily, keeping only the next value from each iterable in memory. Use 
426      :func:`collate` to, for example, perform a n-way mergesort of items that 
427      don't fit in memory. 
428   
429      If a *key* function is specified, the iterables will be sorted according 
430      to its result: 
431   
432          &gt;&gt;&gt; key = lambda s: int(s)  # Sort by numeric value, not by string 
433          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collate(['1', '10'], ['2', '11'], key=key)) 
434          ['1', '2', '10', '11'] 
435   
436   
437      If the *iterables* are sorted in descending order, set *reverse* to 
438      ``True``: 
439   
440          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collate([5, 3, 1], [4, 2, 0], reverse=True)) 
441          [5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0] 
442   
443      If the elements of the passed-in iterables are out of order, you might get 
444      unexpected results. 
445   
446      On Python 3.5+, this function is an alias for :func:`heapq.merge`. 
447   
448      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
449      <span class="s1">warnings.warn(</span>
450          <span class="s2">&quot;collate is no longer part of more_itertools, use heapq.merge&quot;</span><span class="s0">,</span>
451          <span class="s1">DeprecationWarning</span><span class="s0">,</span>
452      <span class="s1">)</span>
453      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">merge(*iterables</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">**kwargs)</span>
454  
455  
456  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">consumer(func):</span>
457      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Decorator that automatically advances a PEP-342-style &quot;reverse iterator&quot; 
458      to its first yield point so you don't have to call ``next()`` on it 
459      manually. 
460   
461          &gt;&gt;&gt; @consumer 
462          ... def tally(): 
463          ...     i = 0 
464          ...     while True: 
465          ...         print('Thing number %s is %s.' % (i, (yield))) 
466          ...         i += 1 
467          ... 
468          &gt;&gt;&gt; t = tally() 
469          &gt;&gt;&gt; t.send('red') 
470          Thing number 0 is red. 
471          &gt;&gt;&gt; t.send('fish') 
472          Thing number 1 is fish. 
473   
474      Without the decorator, you would have to call ``next(t)`` before 
475      ``t.send()`` could be used. 
476   
477      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
478  
479      <span class="s1">@wraps(func)</span>
480      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">wrapper(*args</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">**kwargs):</span>
481          <span class="s1">gen = func(*args</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">**kwargs)</span>
482          <span class="s1">next(gen)</span>
483          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">gen</span>
484  
485      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">wrapper</span>
486  
487  
488  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">ilen(iterable):</span>
489      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the number of items in *iterable*. 
490   
491          &gt;&gt;&gt; ilen(x for x in range(1000000) if x % 3 == 0) 
492          333334 
493   
494      This consumes the iterable, so handle with care. 
495   
496      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
497      <span class="s5"># This approach was selected because benchmarks showed it's likely the</span>
498      <span class="s5"># fastest of the known implementations at the time of writing.</span>
499      <span class="s5"># See GitHub tracker: #236, #230.</span>
500      <span class="s1">counter = count()</span>
501      <span class="s1">deque(zip(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">counter)</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">maxlen=</span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">)</span>
502      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">next(counter)</span>
503  
504  
505  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">iterate(func</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">start):</span>
506      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return ``start``, ``func(start)``, ``func(func(start))``, ... 
507   
508      &gt;&gt;&gt; from itertools import islice 
509      &gt;&gt;&gt; list(islice(iterate(lambda x: 2*x, 1), 10)) 
510      [1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256, 512] 
511   
512      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
513      <span class="s0">while True</span><span class="s1">:</span>
514          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">start</span>
515          <span class="s1">start = func(start)</span>

518  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">with_iter(context_manager):</span>
519      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Wrap an iterable in a ``with`` statement, so it closes once exhausted. 
520   
521      For example, this will close the file when the iterator is exhausted:: 
522   
523          upper_lines = (line.upper() for line in with_iter(open('foo'))) 
524   
525      Any context manager which returns an iterable is a candidate for 
526      ``with_iter``. 
527   
528      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
529      <span class="s0">with </span><span class="s1">context_manager </span><span class="s0">as </span><span class="s1">iterable:</span>
530          <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">iterable</span>
531  
532  
533  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">one(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">too_short=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">too_long=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
534      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the first item from *iterable*, which is expected to contain only 
535      that item. Raise an exception if *iterable* is empty or has more than one 
536      item. 
537   
538      :func:`one` is useful for ensuring that an iterable contains only one item. 
539      For example, it can be used to retrieve the result of a database query 
540      that is expected to return a single row. 
541   
542      If *iterable* is empty, ``ValueError`` will be raised. You may specify a 
543      different exception with the *too_short* keyword: 
544   
545          &gt;&gt;&gt; it = [] 
546          &gt;&gt;&gt; one(it)  # doctest: +IGNORE_EXCEPTION_DETAIL 
547          Traceback (most recent call last): 
548          ... 
549          ValueError: too many items in iterable (expected 1)' 
550          &gt;&gt;&gt; too_short = IndexError('too few items') 
551          &gt;&gt;&gt; one(it, too_short=too_short)  # doctest: +IGNORE_EXCEPTION_DETAIL 
552          Traceback (most recent call last): 
553          ... 
554          IndexError: too few items 
555   
556      Similarly, if *iterable* contains more than one item, ``ValueError`` will 
557      be raised. You may specify a different exception with the *too_long* 
558      keyword: 
559   
560          &gt;&gt;&gt; it = ['too', 'many'] 
561          &gt;&gt;&gt; one(it)  # doctest: +IGNORE_EXCEPTION_DETAIL 
562          Traceback (most recent call last): 
563          ... 
564          ValueError: Expected exactly one item in iterable, but got 'too', 
565          'many', and perhaps more. 
566          &gt;&gt;&gt; too_long = RuntimeError 
567          &gt;&gt;&gt; one(it, too_long=too_long)  # doctest: +IGNORE_EXCEPTION_DETAIL 
568          Traceback (most recent call last): 
569          ... 
570          RuntimeError 
571   
572      Note that :func:`one` attempts to advance *iterable* twice to ensure there 
573      is only one item. See :func:`spy` or :func:`peekable` to check iterable 
574      contents less destructively. 
575   
576      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
577      <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
578  
579      <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
580          <span class="s1">first_value = next(it)</span>
581      <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration </span><span class="s0">as </span><span class="s1">e:</span>
582          <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">(</span>
583              <span class="s1">too_short </span><span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'too few items in iterable (expected 1)'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
584          <span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">from </span><span class="s1">e</span>
585  
586      <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
587          <span class="s1">second_value = next(it)</span>
588      <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
589          <span class="s0">pass</span>
590      <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
591          <span class="s1">msg = (</span>
592              <span class="s2">'Expected exactly one item in iterable, but got {!r}, {!r}, '</span>
593              <span class="s2">'and perhaps more.'</span><span class="s1">.format(first_value</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">second_value)</span>
594          <span class="s1">)</span>
595          <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">too_long </span><span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">ValueError(msg)</span>
596  
597      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">first_value</span>
598  
599  
600  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">distinct_permutations(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">r=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
601      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield successive distinct permutations of the elements in *iterable*. 
602   
603          &gt;&gt;&gt; sorted(distinct_permutations([1, 0, 1])) 
604          [(0, 1, 1), (1, 0, 1), (1, 1, 0)] 
605   
606      Equivalent to ``set(permutations(iterable))``, except duplicates are not 
607      generated and thrown away. For larger input sequences this is much more 
608      efficient. 
609   
610      Duplicate permutations arise when there are duplicated elements in the 
611      input iterable. The number of items returned is 
612      `n! / (x_1! * x_2! * ... * x_n!)`, where `n` is the total number of 
613      items input, and each `x_i` is the count of a distinct item in the input 
614      sequence. 
615   
616      If *r* is given, only the *r*-length permutations are yielded. 
617   
618          &gt;&gt;&gt; sorted(distinct_permutations([1, 0, 1], r=2)) 
619          [(0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 1)] 
620          &gt;&gt;&gt; sorted(distinct_permutations(range(3), r=2)) 
621          [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 0), (1, 2), (2, 0), (2, 1)] 
622   
623      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
624      <span class="s5"># Algorithm: https://w.wiki/Qai</span>
625      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">_full(A):</span>
626          <span class="s0">while True</span><span class="s1">:</span>
627              <span class="s5"># Yield the permutation we have</span>
628              <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple(A)</span>
629  
630              <span class="s5"># Find the largest index i such that A[i] &lt; A[i + 1]</span>
631              <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(size - </span><span class="s4">2</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
632                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">A[i] &lt; A[i + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]:</span>
633                      <span class="s0">break</span>
634              <span class="s5">#  If no such index exists, this permutation is the last one</span>
635              <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
636                  <span class="s0">return</span>
637  
638              <span class="s5"># Find the largest index j greater than j such that A[i] &lt; A[j]</span>
639              <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">j </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(size - </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">i</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
640                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">A[i] &lt; A[j]:</span>
641                      <span class="s0">break</span>
642  
643              <span class="s5"># Swap the value of A[i] with that of A[j], then reverse the</span>
644              <span class="s5"># sequence from A[i + 1] to form the new permutation</span>
645              <span class="s1">A[i]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">A[j] = A[j]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">A[i]</span>
646              <span class="s1">A[i + </span><span class="s4">1 </span><span class="s1">:] = A[: i - size : -</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]  </span><span class="s5"># A[i + 1:][::-1]</span>
647  
648      <span class="s5"># Algorithm: modified from the above</span>
649      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">_partial(A</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">r):</span>
650          <span class="s5"># Split A into the first r items and the last r items</span>
651          <span class="s1">head</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">tail = A[:r]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">A[r:]</span>
652          <span class="s1">right_head_indexes = range(r - </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)</span>
653          <span class="s1">left_tail_indexes = range(len(tail))</span>
654  
655          <span class="s0">while True</span><span class="s1">:</span>
656              <span class="s5"># Yield the permutation we have</span>
657              <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple(head)</span>
658  
659              <span class="s5"># Starting from the right, find the first index of the head with</span>
660              <span class="s5"># value smaller than the maximum value of the tail - call it i.</span>
661              <span class="s1">pivot = tail[-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]</span>
662              <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">right_head_indexes:</span>
663                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">head[i] &lt; pivot:</span>
664                      <span class="s0">break</span>
665                  <span class="s1">pivot = head[i]</span>
666              <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
667                  <span class="s0">return</span>
668  
669              <span class="s5"># Starting from the left, find the first value of the tail</span>
670              <span class="s5"># with a value greater than head[i] and swap.</span>
671              <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">j </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">left_tail_indexes:</span>
672                  <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">tail[j] &gt; head[i]:</span>
673                      <span class="s1">head[i]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">tail[j] = tail[j]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">head[i]</span>
674                      <span class="s0">break</span>
675              <span class="s5"># If we didn't find one, start from the right and find the first</span>
676              <span class="s5"># index of the head with a value greater than head[i] and swap.</span>
677              <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
678                  <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">j </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">right_head_indexes:</span>
679                      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">head[j] &gt; head[i]:</span>
680                          <span class="s1">head[i]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">head[j] = head[j]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">head[i]</span>
681                          <span class="s0">break</span>
682  
683              <span class="s5"># Reverse head[i + 1:] and swap it with tail[:r - (i + 1)]</span>
684              <span class="s1">tail += head[: i - r : -</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">]  </span><span class="s5"># head[i + 1:][::-1]</span>
685              <span class="s1">i += </span><span class="s4">1</span>
686              <span class="s1">head[i:]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">tail[:] = tail[: r - i]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">tail[r - i :]</span>
687  
688      <span class="s1">items = sorted(iterable)</span>
689  
690      <span class="s1">size = len(items)</span>
691      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">r </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
692          <span class="s1">r = size</span>
693  
694      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s4">0 </span><span class="s1">&lt; r &lt;= size:</span>
695          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">_full(items) </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(r == size) </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">_partial(items</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">r)</span>
696  
697      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iter(() </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">r </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">(()</span><span class="s0">,</span><span class="s1">))</span>
698  
699  
700  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">intersperse(e</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n=</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
701      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Intersperse filler element *e* among the items in *iterable*, leaving 
702      *n* items between each filler element. 
703   
704          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(intersperse('!', [1, 2, 3, 4, 5])) 
705          [1, '!', 2, '!', 3, '!', 4, '!', 5] 
706   
707          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(intersperse(None, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], n=2)) 
708          [1, 2, None, 3, 4, None, 5] 
709   
710      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
711      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n == </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
712          <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'n must be &gt; 0'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
713      <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">n == </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
714          <span class="s5"># interleave(repeat(e), iterable) -&gt; e, x_0, e, e, x_1, e, x_2...</span>
715          <span class="s5"># islice(..., 1, None) -&gt; x_0, e, e, x_1, e, x_2...</span>
716          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">islice(interleave(repeat(e)</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable)</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, None</span><span class="s1">)</span>
717      <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
718          <span class="s5"># interleave(filler, chunks) -&gt; [e], [x_0, x_1], [e], [x_2, x_3]...</span>
719          <span class="s5"># islice(..., 1, None) -&gt; [x_0, x_1], [e], [x_2, x_3]...</span>
720          <span class="s5"># flatten(...) -&gt; x_0, x_1, e, x_2, x_3...</span>
721          <span class="s1">filler = repeat([e])</span>
722          <span class="s1">chunks = chunked(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n)</span>
723          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">flatten(islice(interleave(filler</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">chunks)</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, None</span><span class="s1">))</span>
724  
725  
726  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">unique_to_each(*iterables):</span>
727      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return the elements from each of the input iterables that aren't in the 
728      other input iterables. 
729   
730      For example, suppose you have a set of packages, each with a set of 
731      dependencies:: 
732   
733          {'pkg_1': {'A', 'B'}, 'pkg_2': {'B', 'C'}, 'pkg_3': {'B', 'D'}} 
734   
735      If you remove one package, which dependencies can also be removed? 
736   
737      If ``pkg_1`` is removed, then ``A`` is no longer necessary - it is not 
738      associated with ``pkg_2`` or ``pkg_3``. Similarly, ``C`` is only needed for 
739      ``pkg_2``, and ``D`` is only needed for ``pkg_3``:: 
740   
741          &gt;&gt;&gt; unique_to_each({'A', 'B'}, {'B', 'C'}, {'B', 'D'}) 
742          [['A'], ['C'], ['D']] 
743   
744      If there are duplicates in one input iterable that aren't in the others 
745      they will be duplicated in the output. Input order is preserved:: 
746   
747          &gt;&gt;&gt; unique_to_each(&quot;mississippi&quot;, &quot;missouri&quot;) 
748          [['p', 'p'], ['o', 'u', 'r']] 
749   
750      It is assumed that the elements of each iterable are hashable. 
751   
752      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
753      <span class="s1">pool = [list(it) </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">it </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iterables]</span>
754      <span class="s1">counts = Counter(chain.from_iterable(map(set</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">pool)))</span>
755      <span class="s1">uniques = {element </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">element </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">counts </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">counts[element] == </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">}</span>
756      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">[list(filter(uniques.__contains__</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">it)) </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">it </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">pool]</span>
757  
758  
759  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">windowed(seq</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">fillvalue=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">step=</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
760      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return a sliding window of width *n* over the given iterable. 
761   
762          &gt;&gt;&gt; all_windows = windowed([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3) 
763          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(all_windows) 
764          [(1, 2, 3), (2, 3, 4), (3, 4, 5)] 
765   
766      When the window is larger than the iterable, *fillvalue* is used in place 
767      of missing values: 
768   
769          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(windowed([1, 2, 3], 4)) 
770          [(1, 2, 3, None)] 
771   
772      Each window will advance in increments of *step*: 
773   
774          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(windowed([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6], 3, fillvalue='!', step=2)) 
775          [(1, 2, 3), (3, 4, 5), (5, 6, '!')] 
776   
777      To slide into the iterable's items, use :func:`chain` to add filler items 
778      to the left: 
779   
780          &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = [1, 2, 3, 4] 
781          &gt;&gt;&gt; n = 3 
782          &gt;&gt;&gt; padding = [None] * (n - 1) 
783          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(windowed(chain(padding, iterable), 3)) 
784          [(None, None, 1), (None, 1, 2), (1, 2, 3), (2, 3, 4)] 
785      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
786      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n &lt; </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
787          <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'n must be &gt;= 0'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
788      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n == </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
789          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple()</span>
790          <span class="s0">return</span>
791      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">step &lt; </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
792          <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'step must be &gt;= 1'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
793  
794      <span class="s1">window = deque(maxlen=n)</span>
795      <span class="s1">i = n</span>
796      <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">_ </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">map(window.append</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">seq):</span>
797          <span class="s1">i -= </span><span class="s4">1</span>
798          <span class="s0">if not </span><span class="s1">i:</span>
799              <span class="s1">i = step</span>
800              <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple(window)</span>
801  
802      <span class="s1">size = len(window)</span>
803      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">size &lt; n:</span>
804          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple(chain(window</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">repeat(fillvalue</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n - size)))</span>
805      <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s4">0 </span><span class="s1">&lt; i &lt; min(step</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n):</span>
806          <span class="s1">window += (fillvalue</span><span class="s0">,</span><span class="s1">) * i</span>
807          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">tuple(window)</span>
808  
809  
810  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">substrings(iterable):</span>
811      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield all of the substrings of *iterable*. 
812   
813          &gt;&gt;&gt; [''.join(s) for s in substrings('more')] 
814          ['m', 'o', 'r', 'e', 'mo', 'or', 're', 'mor', 'ore', 'more'] 
815   
816      Note that non-string iterables can also be subdivided. 
817   
818          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(substrings([0, 1, 2])) 
819          [(0,), (1,), (2,), (0, 1), (1, 2), (0, 1, 2)] 
820   
821      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
822      <span class="s5"># The length-1 substrings</span>
823      <span class="s1">seq = []</span>
824      <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iter(iterable):</span>
825          <span class="s1">seq.append(item)</span>
826          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">(item</span><span class="s0">,</span><span class="s1">)</span>
827      <span class="s1">seq = tuple(seq)</span>
828      <span class="s1">item_count = len(seq)</span>
829  
830      <span class="s5"># And the rest</span>
831      <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">n </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(</span><span class="s4">2</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">item_count + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
832          <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(item_count - n + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
833              <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">seq[i : i + n]</span>
834  
835  
836  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">substrings_indexes(seq</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">reverse=</span><span class="s0">False</span><span class="s1">):</span>
837      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield all substrings and their positions in *seq* 
838   
839      The items yielded will be a tuple of the form ``(substr, i, j)``, where 
840      ``substr == seq[i:j]``. 
841   
842      This function only works for iterables that support slicing, such as 
843      ``str`` objects. 
844   
845      &gt;&gt;&gt; for item in substrings_indexes('more'): 
846      ...    print(item) 
847      ('m', 0, 1) 
848      ('o', 1, 2) 
849      ('r', 2, 3) 
850      ('e', 3, 4) 
851      ('mo', 0, 2) 
852      ('or', 1, 3) 
853      ('re', 2, 4) 
854      ('mor', 0, 3) 
855      ('ore', 1, 4) 
856      ('more', 0, 4) 
857   
858      Set *reverse* to ``True`` to yield the same items in the opposite order. 
859   
860   
861      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
862      <span class="s1">r = range(</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">len(seq) + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)</span>
863      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">reverse:</span>
864          <span class="s1">r = reversed(r)</span>
865      <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">(</span>
866          <span class="s1">(seq[i : i + L]</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">i</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">i + L) </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">L </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">r </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(len(seq) - L + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)</span>
867      <span class="s1">)</span>
868  
869  
870  <span class="s0">class </span><span class="s1">bucket:</span>
871      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Wrap *iterable* and return an object that buckets it iterable into 
872      child iterables based on a *key* function. 
873   
874          &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = ['a1', 'b1', 'c1', 'a2', 'b2', 'c2', 'b3'] 
875          &gt;&gt;&gt; s = bucket(iterable, key=lambda x: x[0])  # Bucket by 1st character 
876          &gt;&gt;&gt; sorted(list(s))  # Get the keys 
877          ['a', 'b', 'c'] 
878          &gt;&gt;&gt; a_iterable = s['a'] 
879          &gt;&gt;&gt; next(a_iterable) 
880          'a1' 
881          &gt;&gt;&gt; next(a_iterable) 
882          'a2' 
883          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(s['b']) 
884          ['b1', 'b2', 'b3'] 
885   
886      The original iterable will be advanced and its items will be cached until 
887      they are used by the child iterables. This may require significant storage. 
888   
889      By default, attempting to select a bucket to which no items belong  will 
890      exhaust the iterable and cache all values. 
891      If you specify a *validator* function, selected buckets will instead be 
892      checked against it. 
893   
894          &gt;&gt;&gt; from itertools import count 
895          &gt;&gt;&gt; it = count(1, 2)  # Infinite sequence of odd numbers 
896          &gt;&gt;&gt; key = lambda x: x % 10  # Bucket by last digit 
897          &gt;&gt;&gt; validator = lambda x: x in {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}  # Odd digits only 
898          &gt;&gt;&gt; s = bucket(it, key=key, validator=validator) 
899          &gt;&gt;&gt; 2 in s 
900          False 
901          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(s[2]) 
902          [] 
903   
904      &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
905  
906      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__init__(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">key</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">validator=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
907          <span class="s1">self._it = iter(iterable)</span>
908          <span class="s1">self._key = key</span>
909          <span class="s1">self._cache = defaultdict(deque)</span>
910          <span class="s1">self._validator = validator </span><span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">(</span><span class="s0">lambda </span><span class="s1">x: </span><span class="s0">True</span><span class="s1">)</span>
911  
912      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__contains__(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">value):</span>
913          <span class="s0">if not </span><span class="s1">self._validator(value):</span>
914              <span class="s0">return False</span>
915  
916          <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
917              <span class="s1">item = next(self[value])</span>
918          <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
919              <span class="s0">return False</span>
920          <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
921              <span class="s1">self._cache[value].appendleft(item)</span>
922  
923          <span class="s0">return True</span>
924  
925      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">_get_values(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">value):</span>
926          <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot; 
927          Helper to yield items from the parent iterator that match *value*. 
928          Items that don't match are stored in the local cache as they 
929          are encountered. 
930          &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
931          <span class="s0">while True</span><span class="s1">:</span>
932              <span class="s5"># If we've cached some items that match the target value, emit</span>
933              <span class="s5"># the first one and evict it from the cache.</span>
934              <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">self._cache[value]:</span>
935                  <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">self._cache[value].popleft()</span>
936              <span class="s5"># Otherwise we need to advance the parent iterator to search for</span>
937              <span class="s5"># a matching item, caching the rest.</span>
938              <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
939                  <span class="s0">while True</span><span class="s1">:</span>
940                      <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
941                          <span class="s1">item = next(self._it)</span>
942                      <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
943                          <span class="s0">return</span>
944                      <span class="s1">item_value = self._key(item)</span>
945                      <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">item_value == value:</span>
946                          <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">item</span>
947                          <span class="s0">break</span>
948                      <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">self._validator(item_value):</span>
949                          <span class="s1">self._cache[item_value].append(item)</span>
950  
951      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__iter__(self):</span>
952          <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">self._it:</span>
953              <span class="s1">item_value = self._key(item)</span>
954              <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">self._validator(item_value):</span>
955                  <span class="s1">self._cache[item_value].append(item)</span>
956  
957          <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">self._cache.keys()</span>
958  
959      <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">__getitem__(self</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">value):</span>
960          <span class="s0">if not </span><span class="s1">self._validator(value):</span>
961              <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iter(())</span>
962  
963          <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">self._get_values(value)</span>
964  
965  
966  <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">spy(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n=</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
967      <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return a 2-tuple with a list containing the first *n* elements of 
968      *iterable*, and an iterator with the same items as *iterable*. 
969      This allows you to &quot;look ahead&quot; at the items in the iterable without 
970      advancing it. 
971   
972      There is one item in the list by default: 
973   
974          &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = 'abcdefg' 
975          &gt;&gt;&gt; head, iterable = spy(iterable) 
976          &gt;&gt;&gt; head 
977          ['a'] 
978          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(iterable) 
979          ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g'] 
980   
981      You may use unpacking to retrieve items instead of lists: 
982   
983          &gt;&gt;&gt; (head,), iterable = spy('abcdefg') 
984          &gt;&gt;&gt; head 
985          'a' 
986          &gt;&gt;&gt; (first, second), iterable = spy('abcdefg', 2) 
987          &gt;&gt;&gt; first 
988          'a' 
989          &gt;&gt;&gt; second 
990          'b' 
991   
992      The number of items requested can be larger than the number of items in 
993      the iterable: 
994   
995          &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] 
996          &gt;&gt;&gt; head, iterable = spy(iterable, 10) 
997          &gt;&gt;&gt; head 
998          [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] 
999          &gt;&gt;&gt; list(iterable) 
1000         [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] 
1001  
1002     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1003     <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
1004     <span class="s1">head = take(n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">it)</span>
1005 
1006     <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">head.copy()</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">chain(head</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">it)</span>
1007 
1008 
1009 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">interleave(*iterables):</span>
1010     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return a new iterable yielding from each iterable in turn, 
1011     until the shortest is exhausted. 
1012  
1013         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(interleave([1, 2, 3], [4, 5], [6, 7, 8])) 
1014         [1, 4, 6, 2, 5, 7] 
1015  
1016     For a version that doesn't terminate after the shortest iterable is 
1017     exhausted, see :func:`interleave_longest`. 
1018  
1019     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1020     <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">chain.from_iterable(zip(*iterables))</span>
1021 
1022 
1023 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">interleave_longest(*iterables):</span>
1024     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Return a new iterable yielding from each iterable in turn, 
1025     skipping any that are exhausted. 
1026  
1027         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(interleave_longest([1, 2, 3], [4, 5], [6, 7, 8])) 
1028         [1, 4, 6, 2, 5, 7, 3, 8] 
1029  
1030     This function produces the same output as :func:`roundrobin`, but may 
1031     perform better for some inputs (in particular when the number of iterables 
1032     is large). 
1033  
1034     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1035     <span class="s1">i = chain.from_iterable(zip_longest(*iterables</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">fillvalue=_marker))</span>
1036     <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">(x </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">x </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">x </span><span class="s0">is not </span><span class="s1">_marker)</span>

1038 
1039 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">collapse(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">base_type=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">levels=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1040     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Flatten an iterable with multiple levels of nesting (e.g., a list of 
1041     lists of tuples) into non-iterable types. 
1042  
1043         &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = [(1, 2), ([3, 4], [[5], [6]])] 
1044         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collapse(iterable)) 
1045         [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] 
1046  
1047     Binary and text strings are not considered iterable and 
1048     will not be collapsed. 
1049  
1050     To avoid collapsing other types, specify *base_type*: 
1051  
1052         &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = ['ab', ('cd', 'ef'), ['gh', 'ij']] 
1053         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collapse(iterable, base_type=tuple)) 
1054         ['ab', ('cd', 'ef'), 'gh', 'ij'] 
1055  
1056     Specify *levels* to stop flattening after a certain level: 
1057  
1058     &gt;&gt;&gt; iterable = [('a', ['b']), ('c', ['d'])] 
1059     &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collapse(iterable))  # Fully flattened 
1060     ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] 
1061     &gt;&gt;&gt; list(collapse(iterable, levels=1))  # Only one level flattened 
1062     ['a', ['b'], 'c', ['d']] 
1063  
1064     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1065 
1066     <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">walk(node</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">level):</span>
1067         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">(</span>
1068             <span class="s1">((levels </span><span class="s0">is not None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">and </span><span class="s1">(level &gt; levels))</span>
1069             <span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">isinstance(node</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">(str</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">bytes))</span>
1070             <span class="s0">or </span><span class="s1">((base_type </span><span class="s0">is not None</span><span class="s1">) </span><span class="s0">and </span><span class="s1">isinstance(node</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">base_type))</span>
1071         <span class="s1">):</span>
1072             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">node</span>
1073             <span class="s0">return</span>
1074 
1075         <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1076             <span class="s1">tree = iter(node)</span>
1077         <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">TypeError:</span>
1078             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">node</span>
1079             <span class="s0">return</span>
1080         <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1081             <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">child </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">tree:</span>
1082                 <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">walk(child</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">level + </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">)</span>
1083 
1084     <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">walk(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">)</span>

1086 
1087 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">side_effect(func</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">chunk_size=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">before=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">after=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1088     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Invoke *func* on each item in *iterable* (or on each *chunk_size* group 
1089     of items) before yielding the item. 
1090  
1091     `func` must be a function that takes a single argument. Its return value 
1092     will be discarded. 
1093  
1094     *before* and *after* are optional functions that take no arguments. They 
1095     will be executed before iteration starts and after it ends, respectively. 
1096  
1097     `side_effect` can be used for logging, updating progress bars, or anything 
1098     that is not functionally &quot;pure.&quot; 
1099  
1100     Emitting a status message: 
1101  
1102         &gt;&gt;&gt; from more_itertools import consume 
1103         &gt;&gt;&gt; func = lambda item: print('Received {}'.format(item)) 
1104         &gt;&gt;&gt; consume(side_effect(func, range(2))) 
1105         Received 0 
1106         Received 1 
1107  
1108     Operating on chunks of items: 
1109  
1110         &gt;&gt;&gt; pair_sums = [] 
1111         &gt;&gt;&gt; func = lambda chunk: pair_sums.append(sum(chunk)) 
1112         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(side_effect(func, [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2)) 
1113         [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5] 
1114         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(pair_sums) 
1115         [1, 5, 9] 
1116  
1117     Writing to a file-like object: 
1118  
1119         &gt;&gt;&gt; from io import StringIO 
1120         &gt;&gt;&gt; from more_itertools import consume 
1121         &gt;&gt;&gt; f = StringIO() 
1122         &gt;&gt;&gt; func = lambda x: print(x, file=f) 
1123         &gt;&gt;&gt; before = lambda: print(u'HEADER', file=f) 
1124         &gt;&gt;&gt; after = f.close 
1125         &gt;&gt;&gt; it = [u'a', u'b', u'c'] 
1126         &gt;&gt;&gt; consume(side_effect(func, it, before=before, after=after)) 
1127         &gt;&gt;&gt; f.closed 
1128         True 
1129  
1130     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1131     <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1132         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">before </span><span class="s0">is not None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1133             <span class="s1">before()</span>
1134 
1135         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">chunk_size </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1136             <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iterable:</span>
1137                 <span class="s1">func(item)</span>
1138                 <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">item</span>
1139         <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1140             <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">chunk </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">chunked(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">chunk_size):</span>
1141                 <span class="s1">func(chunk)</span>
1142                 <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">chunk</span>
1143     <span class="s0">finally</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1144         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">after </span><span class="s0">is not None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1145             <span class="s1">after()</span>
1146 
1147 
1148 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">sliced(seq</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">strict=</span><span class="s0">False</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1149     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield slices of length *n* from the sequence *seq*. 
1150  
1151     &gt;&gt;&gt; list(sliced((1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), 3)) 
1152     [(1, 2, 3), (4, 5, 6)] 
1153  
1154     By the default, the last yielded slice will have fewer than *n* elements 
1155     if the length of *seq* is not divisible by *n*: 
1156  
1157     &gt;&gt;&gt; list(sliced((1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8), 3)) 
1158     [(1, 2, 3), (4, 5, 6), (7, 8)] 
1159  
1160     If the length of *seq* is not divisible by *n* and *strict* is 
1161     ``True``, then ``ValueError`` will be raised before the last 
1162     slice is yielded. 
1163  
1164     This function will only work for iterables that support slicing. 
1165     For non-sliceable iterables, see :func:`chunked`. 
1166  
1167     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1168     <span class="s1">iterator = takewhile(len</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">(seq[i : i + n] </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">i </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">count(</span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n)))</span>
1169     <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">strict:</span>
1170 
1171         <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">ret():</span>
1172             <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">_slice </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iterator:</span>
1173                 <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">len(_slice) != n:</span>
1174                     <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">&quot;seq is not divisible by n.&quot;</span><span class="s1">)</span>
1175                 <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">_slice</span>
1176 
1177         <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iter(ret())</span>
1178     <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1179         <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">iterator</span>
1180

1182 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">split_at(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">pred</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">maxsplit=-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">keep_separator=</span><span class="s0">False</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1183     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield lists of items from *iterable*, where each list is delimited by 
1184     an item where callable *pred* returns ``True``. 
1185  
1186         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_at('abcdcba', lambda x: x == 'b')) 
1187         [['a'], ['c', 'd', 'c'], ['a']] 
1188  
1189         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_at(range(10), lambda n: n % 2 == 1)) 
1190         [[0], [2], [4], [6], [8], []] 
1191  
1192     At most *maxsplit* splits are done. If *maxsplit* is not specified or -1, 
1193     then there is no limit on the number of splits: 
1194  
1195         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_at(range(10), lambda n: n % 2 == 1, maxsplit=2)) 
1196         [[0], [2], [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]] 
1197  
1198     By default, the delimiting items are not included in the output. 
1199     The include them, set *keep_separator* to ``True``. 
1200  
1201         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_at('abcdcba', lambda x: x == 'b', keep_separator=True)) 
1202         [['a'], ['b'], ['c', 'd', 'c'], ['b'], ['a']] 
1203  
1204     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1205     <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">maxsplit == </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1206         <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">list(iterable)</span>
1207         <span class="s0">return</span>
1208 
1209     <span class="s1">buf = []</span>
1210     <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
1211     <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">it:</span>
1212         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">pred(item):</span>
1213             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">buf</span>
1214             <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">keep_separator:</span>
1215                 <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">[item]</span>
1216             <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">maxsplit == </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1217                 <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">list(it)</span>
1218                 <span class="s0">return</span>
1219             <span class="s1">buf = []</span>
1220             <span class="s1">maxsplit -= </span><span class="s4">1</span>
1221         <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1222             <span class="s1">buf.append(item)</span>
1223     <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">buf</span>

1297 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">split_when(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">pred</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">maxsplit=-</span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1298     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Split *iterable* into pieces based on the output of *pred*. 
1299     *pred* should be a function that takes successive pairs of items and 
1300     returns ``True`` if the iterable should be split in between them. 
1301  
1302     For example, to find runs of increasing numbers, split the iterable when 
1303     element ``i`` is larger than element ``i + 1``: 
1304  
1305         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_when([1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 5, 2, 4, 2], lambda x, y: x &gt; y)) 
1306         [[1, 2, 3, 3], [2, 5], [2, 4], [2]] 
1307  
1308     At most *maxsplit* splits are done. If *maxsplit* is not specified or -1, 
1309     then there is no limit on the number of splits: 
1310  
1311         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_when([1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 5, 2, 4, 2], 
1312         ...                 lambda x, y: x &gt; y, maxsplit=2)) 
1313         [[1, 2, 3, 3], [2, 5], [2, 4, 2]] 
1314  
1315     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1316     <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">maxsplit == </span><span class="s4">0</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1317         <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">list(iterable)</span>
1318         <span class="s0">return</span>
1319 
1320     <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
1321     <span class="s0">try</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1322         <span class="s1">cur_item = next(it)</span>
1323     <span class="s0">except </span><span class="s1">StopIteration:</span>
1324         <span class="s0">return</span>
1325 
1326     <span class="s1">buf = [cur_item]</span>
1327     <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">next_item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">it:</span>
1328         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">pred(cur_item</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">next_item):</span>
1329             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">buf</span>
1330             <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">maxsplit == </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1331                 <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">[next_item] + list(it)</span>
1332                 <span class="s0">return</span>
1333             <span class="s1">buf = []</span>
1334             <span class="s1">maxsplit -= </span><span class="s4">1</span>
1335 
1336         <span class="s1">buf.append(next_item)</span>
1337         <span class="s1">cur_item = next_item</span>
1338 
1339     <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">buf</span>

1341 
1342 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">split_into(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">sizes):</span>
1343     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield a list of sequential items from *iterable* of length 'n' for each 
1344     integer 'n' in *sizes*. 
1345  
1346         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_into([1,2,3,4,5,6], [1,2,3])) 
1347         [[1], [2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] 
1348  
1349     If the sum of *sizes* is smaller than the length of *iterable*, then the 
1350     remaining items of *iterable* will not be returned. 
1351  
1352         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_into([1,2,3,4,5,6], [2,3])) 
1353         [[1, 2], [3, 4, 5]] 
1354  
1355     If the sum of *sizes* is larger than the length of *iterable*, fewer items 
1356     will be returned in the iteration that overruns *iterable* and further 
1357     lists will be empty: 
1358  
1359         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_into([1,2,3,4], [1,2,3,4])) 
1360         [[1], [2, 3], [4], []] 
1361  
1362     When a ``None`` object is encountered in *sizes*, the returned list will 
1363     contain items up to the end of *iterable* the same way that itertools.slice 
1364     does: 
1365  
1366         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(split_into([1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,0], [2,3,None])) 
1367         [[1, 2], [3, 4, 5], [6, 7, 8, 9, 0]] 
1368  
1369     :func:`split_into` can be useful for grouping a series of items where the 
1370     sizes of the groups are not uniform. An example would be where in a row 
1371     from a table, multiple columns represent elements of the same feature 
1372     (e.g. a point represented by x,y,z) but, the format is not the same for 
1373     all columns. 
1374     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1375     <span class="s5"># convert the iterable argument into an iterator so its contents can</span>
1376     <span class="s5"># be consumed by islice in case it is a generator</span>
1377     <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
1378 
1379     <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">size </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">sizes:</span>
1380         <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">size </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1381             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">list(it)</span>
1382             <span class="s0">return</span>
1383         <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1384             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">list(islice(it</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">size))</span>

1387 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">padded(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">fillvalue=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">n=</span><span class="s0">None, </span><span class="s1">next_multiple=</span><span class="s0">False</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1388     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Yield the elements from *iterable*, followed by *fillvalue*, such that 
1389     at least *n* items are emitted. 
1390  
1391         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(padded([1, 2, 3], '?', 5)) 
1392         [1, 2, 3, '?', '?'] 
1393  
1394     If *next_multiple* is ``True``, *fillvalue* will be emitted until the 
1395     number of items emitted is a multiple of *n*:: 
1396  
1397         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(padded([1, 2, 3, 4], n=3, next_multiple=True)) 
1398         [1, 2, 3, 4, None, None] 
1399  
1400     If *n* is ``None``, *fillvalue* will be emitted indefinitely. 
1401  
1402     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1403     <span class="s1">it = iter(iterable)</span>
1404     <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n </span><span class="s0">is None</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1405         <span class="s0">yield from </span><span class="s1">chain(it</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">repeat(fillvalue))</span>
1406     <span class="s0">elif </span><span class="s1">n &lt; </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1407         <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'n must be at least 1'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
1408     <span class="s0">else</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1409         <span class="s1">item_count = </span><span class="s4">0</span>
1410         <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">it:</span>
1411             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">item</span>
1412             <span class="s1">item_count += </span><span class="s4">1</span>
1413 
1414         <span class="s1">remaining = (n - item_count) % n </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">next_multiple </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">n - item_count</span>
1415         <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">_ </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">range(remaining):</span>
1416             <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">fillvalue</span>

1419 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">repeat_last(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">default=</span><span class="s0">None</span><span class="s1">):</span>
1420     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;After the *iterable* is exhausted, keep yielding its last element. 
1421  
1422         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(islice(repeat_last(range(3)), 5)) 
1423         [0, 1, 2, 2, 2] 
1424  
1425     If the iterable is empty, yield *default* forever:: 
1426  
1427         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(islice(repeat_last(range(0), 42), 5)) 
1428         [42, 42, 42, 42, 42] 
1429  
1430     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1431     <span class="s1">item = _marker</span>
1432     <span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">iterable:</span>
1433         <span class="s0">yield </span><span class="s1">item</span>
1434     <span class="s1">final = default </span><span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">item </span><span class="s0">is </span><span class="s1">_marker </span><span class="s0">else </span><span class="s1">item</span>

1438 <span class="s0">def </span><span class="s1">distribute(n</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">iterable):</span>
1439     <span class="s3">&quot;&quot;&quot;Distribute the items from *iterable* among *n* smaller iterables. 
1440  
1441         &gt;&gt;&gt; group_1, group_2 = distribute(2, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]) 
1442         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(group_1) 
1443         [1, 3, 5] 
1444         &gt;&gt;&gt; list(group_2) 
1445         [2, 4, 6] 
1446  
1447     If the length of *iterable* is not evenly divisible by *n*, then the 
1448     length of the returned iterables will not be identical: 
1449  
1450         &gt;&gt;&gt; children = distribute(3, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) 
1451         &gt;&gt;&gt; [list(c) for c in children] 
1452         [[1, 4, 7], [2, 5], [3, 6]] 
1453  
1454     If the length of *iterable* is smaller than *n*, then the last returned 
1455     iterables will be empty: 
1456  
1457         &gt;&gt;&gt; children = distribute(5, [1, 2, 3]) 
1458         &gt;&gt;&gt; [list(c) for c in children] 
1459         [[1], [2], [3], [], []] 
1460  
1461     This function uses :func:`itertools.tee` and may require significant 
1462     storage. If you need the order items in the smaller iterables to match the 
1463     original iterable, see :func:`divide`. 
1464  
1465     &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
1466     <span class="s0">if </span><span class="s1">n &lt; </span><span class="s4">1</span><span class="s1">:</span>
1467         <span class="s0">raise </span><span class="s1">ValueError(</span><span class="s2">'n must be at least 1'</span><span class="s1">)</span>
1468 
1469     <span class="s1">children = tee(iterable</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">n)</span>
1470     <span class="s0">return </span><span class="s1">[islice(it</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">index</span><span class="s0">, None, </span><span class="s1">n) </span><span class="s0">for </span><span class="s1">index</span><span class="s0">, </span><span class="s1">it </span><span class="s0">in </span><span class="s1">enumerate(children)]</span>
1471
